Of resolutions and desires; this sullenness
Is scurvy, I like it not,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Be modest.
And do not learn Cesario how to prostitute
The riot of thy hopes to common folly;
Take a sad woman's word, howe'er thou dotest
Upon the present graces of thy greatness,
Yet I am not fallen so below my constancy
To virtue, nor the care which I once tendered
For thy behoof that I prefer a sentence
Of cruelty before my honour.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Honour!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Hear me, thou seest this girl! now the comfort
Of my last days. She is the only pledge
Of a bed truly noble, she had a father
(I need not speak him more than thou remember'st)
Whom to dishonour by a meaner choice,
Were injury and infamy,

sp.speaker: Claris.
sp.l: To goodness,
To time and virtuous mention.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have vowed,
Observe me now Cesario, that howe'er
I may be forced to marry, yet no tyranny,
Persuasions, flattery, gifts, entreats, or tortures,
Shall draw me to a second bed.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis just too

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Yes and 'tis just Clarissa. I allow
The Duke's late sentence, am resolved young man
To be thy wife, but when the ceremony
Of marriage is performed, in life I will be
Though not in name a widow.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Pray a word tee,
Shall I in earnest never be your bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Never, o never; and 'tis for your good too.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Prove that.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas too many years are numbered
In my account to entertain the benefit
Which youth in thee Cesario and ability
Might hope for and require, it were injustice
To rob a gentleman deserving memory
Of issue to preserve it.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: No more herein,
You are an excellent pattern of true piety,
Let me now turn your advocate. Pray look into
The order of the Duke, jnjoynd, admit
I satisfy the sentence without marriage
With you, how then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cesario.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: If I know
How to acquit your fears, yet keep th'injunction
In every clause whole and entire, your charity
Will call me still your servant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still my son.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Right madam, now you have it, still your son.
The genius of your blessings hath instructed
Your tongue oraculously, we will forget
How once I and Clarissa interchanged
The ties of brother and of sister, henceforth
New style us man and wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By what authority

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Heaven's great appointment, yet in all my dotage
On thy perfections, when I thought Clarissa
We had been pledges of one womb, no loose
No wanton heat of youth, desired to claim
Priority in thy affections, other
Than nature might commend. Chastely I tendered
Thy farewell as a brother ought; but since
Our bloods are strangers, let our hearts contract
A long life-lasting unity, for this way
The sentence is to be observed or no way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then no way.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: I expected other answer madam from you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, every age shall curse me,
The monster, and the prodigy of nature,
Horrors beyond extremity,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray mother confine the violence of grief

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Yes mother, pray do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus some catch at a matron's honour
By flying lust to plot incestuous witchcrafts,
More terrible than whoredoms; cruel mercy
When to preserve the body from a death
The soul is strangled.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: This is more than passion.
It comes near to distraction.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am quieted.
Cesario, thou mayest tell the Duke securely
Alberto's titles, honours and revenues,
The Duke may give away, enjoy them thou.
Clarissa's birthright, Mariana's dower
Thou shalt be lord of; turn us to the world
Unpitied and unfriended, yet my bed
Thou never sleepest in; as for her; she hears me,
If she as much as in a thought's consent;
That thou mayest call her wife, a mother's curse
Shall never leave her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: As a brother once
I loved you, as a noble friend yet honour ye,
But for a husband sir, I dare not own you,
My faith is given already.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: To a villain, I'll cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why this is more than passion?
It comes near a distraction.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Call to mind sir.
How much you have abated of that goodness
Which once reigned in ye, they appeared so lovely
That such as friendship led to observation
Courted the great example.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Left and flattered into abroad derision

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why d'ye think so?
My lord Baptista, is your son grown cold
In hasting on the marriage, which his vows
Have sealed to my wronged daughter?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: We come lady, to consummate the contract.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: With Mentivole? is he the man?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Clarissa's, troth and mine,
Cesario are recorded in a character
So plain and certain, that except the hand
Of heaven, which writ it first, would blot it out again,
No human power can raze it.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: But say you so too? young lady,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I should else betray
My heart to falsehood, and my tongue to perjury.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Madam, you know the sentence.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: From the Duke,
I have particular comforts which require
A private ear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall approve it gladly,
We are resolved Cesario.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Be not insolent upon a prince's favour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Lose no glory,
Your younger years have purchased.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: And deserved too you've many worthy friends.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Preserve and use them. Exeunt: manet Caesar.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Good, very good, why here's a compliment
Of mirth in desperation, I could curse
My fate. O with what speed men tumble down
From hopes that soar too high. Biancha now
May scorn me justly too, Clarissa married,
Alberto's widow resolute, Biancha
Refused, and I forsaken, let me study,
I can but die a bachelor that's the worst on't. Exit.

div.stage: Enter host, tailor, muliter, dancer, pedant, coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Come gentlemen,
This is the day that our great artist hath
Promised to give all your several suits satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Dancer.
sp.l: Is he stirring?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: He hath been at his book these two hours.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: He's a rare physician.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why I'll tell you,
Were Paracelsus the german now
Living, heed take up his single rapier against his
Terrible long sword, he makes it a matter of nothing
To cure the gout, sore eyes he takes out as familiarly,
Washes them, and puts them in again,
As you'd blanch almonds.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: They say he can make gold.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Ay, ay, he learned it of Kelly in Germany.
There's not a chemist
In Christendom can go beyond him for multiplying.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Take heed then,
He get not up your daughter's belly my host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: You are a merry gentleman
And the man of art will love you the better.

sp.speaker: Dancer.
sp.l: Does he love mirth and crotchets?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: O he's the most courteous physician,
You may drink or drab in's company freely,
The better he knows how your disease grows,
The better he knows how to cure it.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: But I wonder my host
He has no more resort of ladies to him.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: O divers of them have great belief in conjurer's
Lechery is a great help to the quality.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: He's scarce known to be in town yet,
Ere long we shall have 'em come
Hurrying hither in featherbeds.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: How? bedridden.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: No sir, in featherbeds that move upon 4 wheels in Spanish caroches.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Pray acquaint him we give attendance.

sp.speaker: Host,
sp.l: I shall gentlemen. I would fain be rid
Of these rascals, but that they raise profit
To my wine-cellar;
When I have made use of them sufficiently,
I will entreat the conjurer to tie crackers to their tails,
And send them packing.

div.stage: Enter Forobosco as in his study. (A paper)

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Come hither mine host look here.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A challenge from my man.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: For breaking's pate?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: He writes here if I meet him not
Ith' field within this half hour,
I shall hear more from him.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: O sir, mind your profit,
Ne'er think of the rascal, here are the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Morrow my worthy clients,
What are you all prepared of your questions?
That I may give my resolution upon them,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are sir.

sp.speaker: Pedant,
sp.l: And have brought our money.

sp.speaker: Foro
sp.l: Each then in order,
And differ not for precedency.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I am buying of an office sir,
And to that purpose I would fain learn
To dissemble cunningly.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Do you come to me for that? you should rather
Have gone to a cunning woman.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: Ay sir but their instructions are but like women,
Pretty well but not to the depth, as I do have it,
You are a conjurer, the devil's master,
And I would learn it from you so exactly,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That the devil himself
Might not go beyond you,

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: You are ith' right sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: And so your money for your purchase
Might come in again within a 12 month.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I would be a graduate sir, no freshman.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Here's my hand sir,
I will make you dissemble so methodically,
As if the devil should be sent from the great Turk,
In the shape of an ambassador
To set all the christian princes at variance.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I cannot with any modesty desire any more,
There's your money sir,

sp.speaker: Foco.
sp.l: For the art of dissembling.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: My suit sir will be news to you when I tell it,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Pray on.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: I would set up a press here in Italy,
To write all the coranto for Christendom.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That's news indeed,
And how would you employ me in't?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Marry sir, from you
I would gain my intelligence.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: I conceive you, you would have me furnish you
With a spirit to inform you.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: But as quiet a devil as the woman,
The first day and a half after she's married,
I can by no means endure a terrible one.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: No, no, I'll qualify him,
He shall not fright you,
It shall be the ghost of some lying stationer,
sp.p: A spirit shall look as if butter would not melt in his mouth, a new Mercurius Gallobelgicus.

sp.speaker: Coxc.
sp.l: O there was a captain was rare at it,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Ne'er think of him,
Though that captain writ a full hand gallop,
And wasted indeed more harmless paper then
Ever did laxative physic,
Yet will I make you to out-scribble him,
And set down what you please,
The world shall better believe you.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Worthy sir I thank you, there's money.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A new office
For writing pragmatical currantoes

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: I am a schoolmaster sir,
And would fain confer with you
About erecting 4 new sects of religion at Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: What the devil should
New sects of religion do there?

sp.speaker: Pedaot.
sp.l: I assure you I would get
A great deal of money by it.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: And what are the 4 new sects
Of religion you would plant there?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why that's it I come about sir,
'Tis a devil of your raising must invent 'em,
I confess I am too weak to compass it.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: So sir, than you make it a matter of no difficulty
To have them tolerated.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Trouble not yourself for that,
Let but your devil set them a foot once,
I have weavers, and gingerbread makers,
And mighty aquavitae-men, shall set them a going.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: This is somewhat difficult,
And will ask some conference with the devil.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Take your own leisure sir,
I have another business too, because I mean
To leave Italy, and bury myself in those nether parts
Of the low countries.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: What's that sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Marry I would fain make 9 days to the week, for the more ample benefit of the captain.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: You have a shrewd pate sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: But how this might be compassed?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Compassed easily; 'tis but making
A new almanac, and dividing the compass
Of the year into larger pennyworths,
As a chandler with his compass makes
A geometric proportion of the holland cheese
He retails by stivers.
But for getting of it licenced.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Trouble not yourself with that sir,
There's your money,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: For four new sects of religions,
And 9 days to the week.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: To be brought in at general pay-days,
Write I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: At general pay-days.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: I am by profession a tailor,
You have heard of me.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Yes sir, and will not steal from you
The least part of that commendation I have heard uttered.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: I take measure of your worth sir,
And because I will not afflict you with any large bill
Of circumstances, I will snip off particulars.
I would fain invent some strange
And exquisite new fashions.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Are you not travelled sir.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Yes sir, but have observed all we can see
Or invent are but old ones with new names to 'em,
Now I would some way or other grow more curious.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Let me see to devise new fashions.
Were you never in the moon?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: In the moon tavern! yes sir: often.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: No, I do mean in the new world,
In the world that's in the moon yonder.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: How? A new world ith' moon?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Yes I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: And peopled?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Oh most fantastically peopled.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Nay certain then there's work for tailors?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That there is I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Yet I have talked with a Scotch tailor
That never discovered so much to me,
Though he has travailed far, and was a pedlar in Poland.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That was out of his way,
This lies beyond China,
You would study new fashions you say?
Take my council, make a voyage,
And discover that new world.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Shall I be a moon-man?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: I am of opinion, the people of that world
(If they be like the nature of that climate they live in)
Do vary the fashion of their clothes oftener than any
Quicksilvered nation in Europe.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Not unlikely, but what should that be we call
The man in the moon then?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Why 'tis nothing but an Englishman
That stands there stark naked,
With a pair of shires in one hand,
And a great bundle of broad cloth in the other
(Which resembles the bush of thorns)
Cutting out of new fashions.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.l: I have heard somewhat like this,
But how shall I get thither?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: I'll make a new compass shall direct you.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Certain?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Count me else for no man of direction.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: There's 20 ducats in hand, at my return
I'll give you a 100.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A new voyage to discover new fashions.

sp.speaker: Muleteer
sp.l: I have been a traveler too sir,
That have showed strange beasts in Christendom,
And got money by them, but I find the trade to decay.
Your chameleon, or East-indian hedgehog
Gets very little money, and your elephant devours
So much bread, brings in so little profit,
His keeper were better every morning
Cram 15 tailors with white manchet,
I would have some new spectacle,
And one that might be more attractive.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Let me see, were you ever in Spain?

sp.speaker: Muleteer
sp.p: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I would have you go to Madrill, and against some great festival, when the court lies there, provide a great and spacious English ox, and road him whole, with a pudding in's belly; that would be the eight wonder of the world in those parts I assure you.

sp.speaker: Muleteer
sp.p: A rare project without question.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Go beyond all their garlic olla Podrithoes, though you sod one in Gargantua's cauldron, bring in more money, than all the monsters of Afrique.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Good sir do your best for him; he's of my acquaintance, and one if ye knew him —

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He was once a man of infinite letters.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: A scholar?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: No sir, a packet carrier, which is always a man of many letters, yond know: than he was mule-driver, now he's a gentleman, and feeds monsters.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: A most ungrateful calling.

sp.speaker: Muleteer
sp.p: There's money for your direction; the price of the ox sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A hundred French crowns, for it must be a Lincolnshire ox, and a prime one:
For a rare and monstrous spectacle, to be seen at Madrill.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.p: Pray forbear sir, we shall have a new quarrel.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You durst not meet me ith' field, I am therefore come to spoil your market.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: What's the news with you sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Gentlemen, you that come hither to be most abominably cheated, listen, and be as wise as your planet will suffer you, keep your money, be not gulled, be not laughed at.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.p: What means this? would I had my money again in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: The fellow is full of malice, do not mind him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This professed cheating rogue was my master, and I confess myself a more preternotorious rogue than himself, in so long keeping his villainous counsel.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Come, come, I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No cozener, thou wouldst not hear me, I do but dare thee to suffer me to speak, and than thou and all thy devils spit fire, and spout aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Speak on, I freely permit thee.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why then know all you simple animals, you whose purses are ready to cast the calf, if they have not cast it already, if you give any credit this juggling rascal, you are worse than simple widgins, and will be drawn into the net by this decoy duck, this tame cheater.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, pray mark him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: He does profess physic, and counjuring; for his physic; he has but two medicines for all manner of diseases; when he was i'th low countries, he used nothing but buttered beer, coloured with alicant, for all kind of maladies, and that he called his Catholic medicine; sure the ducth smelled out it was buttered beer, else they would never have endured it for the name's sake: then does he minister a grated dogs turd instead of rhubarb, many times of unicorn's horn, which working strongly with the conceit of the patient, would make them bescummer to the height of a mighty purgation.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: The rogue has studied this invective.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Now for his conjuring, the witches of Lapland are the devil's char-womens to him, for they will sell a man a wind to some purpose; he sells wind, and tells you forty lies over and over.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: I thought what we should find of him.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Hold your prating, be not you an heretic.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Conjure! I'll tell you, all the devil's names he calls upon, are but fustian names, gathered out of Welsh heraldry; in brief, he is a rogue of six reprieves, four pardons of course, thrice pilloried, twice sung lacrymae to the virginals of a cart's tail, has five times been in the galleys, and will never truly run himself out of breath, till he comes to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: You have heard worthy gentlemen, what this lying detracting rascal has vomited.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Yes certain, but we have a better trust in you, for you have ta'ne our money.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I have so, truth is he was my servant, and for some chastisement I gave him, he does practise thus upon me; speak truly sirrah, are you certain I cannot conjure?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Conjure! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but be very sure of it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Sure of it? why I'll make a bargain with thee, before all these gentlemen, use all thy art, all thy roguery, and make me do any thing before all this company I have not a mind to, I'll first give thee leave to claim me for thy bond slave, and when thou hast done hang me.

sp.speaker: Foro,
sp.p: 'Tis a match, sirrah, I'll make you caper ith' air presently.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I have too solid a body, and my belief is like a Puritans on Good-friday, too high fed with capon.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I will first send thee to Greek land for a haunch of venison, just of the thickness of thine own tallow.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I'll not stir an inch for thee.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thence to Amboyna ith' East indies, for pepper to bake it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: To Amboyna? so I might be peppered.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Then will I convey thee stark naked to Develing to beg a pair of brogs, to hide thy mountainous buttocks.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And no doublet to 'em?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: No sir, I intend to send you of a sleeveless errand; but before you vanish, in regard you say I cannot conjure, and are so stupid, and opinionated a slave, that neither I, nor my art can compel you to do any thing that's beyond your own pleasure, the gentlemen shall have some sport; you cannot endure a cat sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What's that to thee juggler?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Nor you'll do nothing at my entreaty?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Sit gentlemen, and whatsoever you see, be not frighted;

sp.speaker: Hostess:
sp.p: Alas I can endure no conjuring.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Stir not wife.

sp.speaker: Bian:
sp.p: Pray let me go sir, I am not fit for these fooleries.

sp.speaker: Host:
sp.p: Move not daughter.

sp.speaker: For:
sp.p: I will make you dance a new dance called leapfrog.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fro:
sp.p: And as naked as a frog.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I defy thee.

div.stage: Foro. looks in a book, strikes with his wand, music plays. Enter 4. Boys shaped like frogs, and dance.

sp.speaker: Pedant:
sp.l: Spirits of the water in the likeness of frogs.
Tay: he has fished fair believe me.

sp.speaker: Muleteer
sp.p: See, see, he sweats and trembles.

sp.speaker: Foro:
sp.p: Are you come to your quavers?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I'll make you run division on that o's ere I leave you; look you, here are the playfellows that are so endeared to you; come sir, first unease, and then dance, nay I'll make him dance stark naked.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: O let him have his shirt on, and his mogul's breeches, here are women ith' house.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well for their sakes he shall.

div.stage: Clown tears off his doublet, making strange faces as if compelled to it, falls into the dance.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: He dances, what a lying rogue was this to say the gentleman could not conjure?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: He does prettily well, but 'tis voluntary, I assure you, I have no hand in't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: As you are a conjurer, and a rare artist, free me from these couplets; of all creatures I cannot endure a frog.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: But your dancing is voluntary, I can compel you to nothing.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.p: O me, daughter, let's take heed of this fellow, he'll make us dance naked, an' we vex him.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Now cut capers sirrah, I'll plague that chin of yours.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O, o, o, my kidneys are roasted, I drop away like a pound of butter roasted.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.p: He will dance himself to death.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: No matter I'll sell his fat to the pothecaries, and repair my injury that way.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Enough in conscience.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well, at your entreaty vanish. And now I will only make him break his neck in doing a summersault, and that's all the revenge I mean to take of him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O gentlemen, what a rogue was I to belie so an approved master in the noble dark science? you can witness, this I did only to spoil his practice and deprive you of the happiness of enjoying his worthy labours; rogue that I was to do it, pray sir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: With what face canst thou ask it?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: With such a face as I deserve, with a hanging look, as all here can testify.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well gentlemen, that you may perceive the goodness of my temper, I will entertain this rogue again in hope of amendment, for should I turn him off, he would be hanged.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You may read that in this foul copy.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Only with this promise, you shall never cozen any of my patients.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And remember hence forward, that though I cannot conjure, I can make you dance sirrah, go get yourself into the cottage again. — Enter Caesario.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I will never more dance leap frog: now I have got you into credit, hold it up, and cozen them in abundance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: O rare rascal— exit clown.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: How now, a Frankford mart here, a mountebank, and his worshipful auditory.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: They are my guests sir.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: A — upon them, show your juggling tricks in some other room.

sp.speaker: Host,
sp.p: And why not here sir?

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: Hence, or sirrah I shall spoil your figure flinging, and all their radical questions.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Sir we vanish. — exeunt. Manet host. And Caesar.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Signior Caesario, you make bold with me,
And somewhat I must tell you to a degree
Of ill manners, they are my guests, and men I live by,
And I would know by what authority
You command thus far.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: By my interest in your daughter.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Interest do you call't? as i remember I never put her out to usury on that condition.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.p: Pray thee be not angry.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.l: I am come to make thee happy, and her happy:
She's here; alas my pretty soul, I am come
To give assurance that's beyond thy hope,
Or thy belief, I bring repentance about me,
And satisfaction, I will marry thee.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: As I live I will, but do not entertained
With too quick an apprehension of joy,
For that may hurt thee, I have heard some die of't,

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Do not fear me.

sp.speaker: Caesar
sp.l: Then thou think'st I feign
This protestation, I will instantly
Before this testimony, my new alliance,
Contract myself unto thee, than I hope
We may be more private.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: But thou shalt not sir,
For so has many a maidenhead been lost, and many a bastard gotten,

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Then to give you the best of any assurance in the world,
Entreat thy father to go fetch a priest
We will instantly to bed, and there be married.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Pride hath not yet forsaken you I see,
Though prosperity has.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Sir you are too confident
To fashion to yourself a dream of purchase
When you are a beggar,

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: You are bold with me.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.l: Do we not know your value is cried down
Fourscore i'th hundred.

sp.speaker: Bian
sp.l: O sir I did love you
With such a fixed heart, that in that minute
Wherein you slighted, or contemned me rather,
I took a vow to obey your last decree,
And never more look up at any hope
Should bring me comfort that way, and though since
Your foster-mother, and the fair Clarissa
Have in the way of marriage despised you,
That hath not any way bred my revenge,
But compassion rather. I have found
So much sorrow in the way to a chaste wedlock
That here I will set down, and never wish
To come to'th journey's end. Your suit to me
Henceforth be ever silenced.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: My Bianca.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.l: Henceforward pray forbear her and my house:
She's a poor virtuous wench, yet her estate
May weigh with yours in a gold balance.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Yes, and her birth in any herald's office in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.l: It may prove so:
When you'll say, you have leapt a Whiteing. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ces,
sp.l: How far am I grown behind hand with fortune?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Here's Cesario ▪
My son sir is tomorrow to be married
Unto the fair Clarissa,

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: We hope you'll be a guest there?

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: No I will not grace your triumph so much.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I will not tax your breeding.
But it alters not your birth sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: O sir do not grieve him,
He has to much affliction already. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: Every way scorned and lost,
Shame follow you
For I am grown most miserable.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: Sir do you know a lady's son in town here
They call Cesario?

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: There's none such I assure thee;

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: I was told you were the man.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: A — on't. You are melancholy, will you drink sir?

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.p: With me sir; despise not this pitched canvas; the time was we have known them lined with Spanish ducats: I have news for you:

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: For me!

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: Not unless you'll drink;
We are like our sea provision, once out of pickle,
We require abundance of drink; I have news to tell you
That were you prince,
Would make you send your mandate
To have a thousand bonfires made ith' city,
And pissed out again with nothing but Greek wine.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: Come, I will drink with thee howsoever,

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.p: And upon these terms I will utter my mind to you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Alberoto, Prospero, Juliana, and sailors.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: Shall we bring your necessaries ashore my lord?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do what you please, I am land-sick, worse by far
Then ere I was at sea.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Collect yourself

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: O my most worthy Prospero, my best friend,
The noble favour I received from thee
In freeing me from the Turks I now account
Worse than my death; for I shall never live
To make requital; what do you attend for?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: To understand your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: They do mock me;
I do protest I have no kind of pleasure
In any thing i'th world, but in thy friendship,
I must ever except that.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p: Pray leave him, leave him. — exeunt sailors.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: The news I heard related since my landing
Of the division of my family,
How is it possible for any man
To bear't with a set patience?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: You have suffered
Since your imprisonment more weighty sorrows.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Ay, than I was a man of flesh and blood,
Now I am made up of fire, to the full height
Of a deadly calenture; o these vild women
That are so ill preservers of men's honours,
They cannot govern their own honesties.
That I should thirty and odd winters feed
My expectation of a noble heir,
And by a woman's falsehood find him now
A fiction, a mere dream of what he was;
And yet I love him still.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: In my opinion
The sentence (On this trial) from the Duke
Was noble, to repair Cesarios' loss
With the marriage of your wife, had you been dead.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: By your favour but it was not, I conceive
Was disparagement to my name, to have my widow
Match with a falconer's son, and yet believe't
I love the youth still, and much pity him.
I do remember at my going to sea,
Upon a quarrel, and a hurt received
From young Mentivole, my rage so far
O'ertopped my nobler temper, I gave charge
To have his hand cut off, which since I heard,
And to my comfort, brave Caesario,
Worthily prevented.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: And 'twas nobly done.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Yet the revenge, for this intent of mine
Hath bred much slaughter in our families,
And yet my wife (Which infinitely moans me)
Intends to marry my sole heir Clarissa
To the head branch of the other faction.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: 'Tis the mean to work reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Between whom?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Yourself, and the worthy Baptista.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: O you have been of a noble and remarkable friendship,
And by this match 'tis generally in Florence
Hoped, 'twill fully be reconciled; to me
'Twould be absolute content.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: And to myself, I have main interest in it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Noble sir, you may command my heart to break for you
But never to bend that way; poor Caesario
When thou puffedst on thy mournful willow garland,
Thy enemy shall be suited (I do vow)
In the same livery, my Caesario
Loved as my foster child, though not my son,
Which in some countries formerly were barbarous,
Was a name held most affectionate; thou art lost,
Unfortunate young man, not only slighted
Where thou received'st thy breeding, but since scorned
Ith' way of marriage, by the poor Bianca
The innkeepers daughter.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I have heard of that too;
But let not that afflict you; for this lady
May happily deliver at more leisure
A circumstance may draw a fair event,
Better than you can hope for.
For this present we must leave you,
And shall visit you again within these two hours.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Ever to me most welcome, — oh my Caesario.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I am none of yours sir, so 'tis protested;
And I humbly beg,
Since 'tis not in your power to preserve me
Any longer in a noble course of life,
Give me a worthy death.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: The youth is mad.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Nay sir, I will instruct you in a way
To kill me honourably.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: That were most strange.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: I am turning pirate, you may be employed
By the Duke to fetch me in; and in a sea-fight
Give me a noble grave.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Questionless he's mad; I would give any doctor
A thousand crowns to free him from this sorrow.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.p: Here's the physician. — shows a poniard

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Hold sir, I did say
To free you from the sorrow, not from life.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: Why life and sorrow are unseparable.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Be comforted Caesario, Mentivole
Shall not marry Clarissa.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: No sir, ere he shall, I'll kill him.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: But you forfeit your own life then.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: That's worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Caesario, be thyself, be mine Caesario,
Make not thyself uncapable of that portion
I have full purpose to confer upon thee;
By falling into madness, bear thy wrongs
With noble patience, the afflicted friend
Which ever in all actions crowns the end.

sp.speaker: Ces.
sp.l: You well awake me ▪ nay recovered me
Both to sense and full life, o most noble sir,
Though I have lost my fortune, and lost you
For a worthy father: yet I will not lose
My former virtue, my integrity
Shall not yet forsake me; but as the wild ivy,
Spreads and thrives better in some piteous ruin
Of tower, or defaced temple, than it does
Planted by a new building - so shall I
Make my adversity my instrument
To wind me up into a full content.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: 'Tis worthily resolved; our first adventure
Is to stop the marriage; for thy other losses,
Practised by a woman's malice, but account them
Like conjurers winds raised to a fearful blast,
And do some mischief, but do never last. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Now sir, will you not acknowledge that I have mightily advancte your practice?

sp.speaker: Forobos.
sp.p: 'Tis confessed, and I will make thee a great man for't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I take a course to do that myself, for I drink sack in abundance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: O my rare rascal. We must remove.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Any whither: Europe is too little to be cozened by us, I am ambitious to go to the East-indies, thou and I to ride on our brace of elephants.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And for my part I long to be in England again; you will never get so much as in England, we have shifted many countries, and many names: but trance the world over you shall never purse up so much gold as when you were in England, and called yourself doctor lamb-stones.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: 'Twas an attractive name I confess, women were then my only admirers.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And all their visits was either to further their lust, or revenge injuries.

sp.speaker: Foro
sp.p: You should have forty in a morning beleaguer my closet, and strive who should be cozened first, amongst fourscore lovesick weighting women that has come to me in a morning to learn what fortune should betide them in their first marriage, I have found above 94 to have lost their maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: By their own confession, but I was fain to be your male midwife, and work it out of them by circumstance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thou wast, and yet for all this frequent resort of women and thy handling of their urinals and their cases, thou art not given to lechery, what should be the reason of it? thou hast wholesome flesh enough about thee; methinks the devil should tempt thee to't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What need he do that, when he makes me his instrument to tempt others.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thou canst not choose but utter thy rare good parts; thou wast an excellent bawd I acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, and what I have done that way I will spare to speak of all you and I have done sir, and though we should —

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: We will for England, that's for certain.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: We shall never want there.

sp.speaker: Foro,
sp.p: Want? the court of wards shall want money first, for I profess myself lord Paramount over fools and mad-folks.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Do but store yourself with lies enough against you come thither,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Why that's all the familiarity I ever had with the devil, my gift of lying, they say he's the father of lies, and though I cannot conjure, yet I profess myself to be one of his poor gossips. I will now reveal to thee a rare piece of service.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What is it my most worshipful doctor lambstones.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: There is a captain come lately from sea,
They call prosper I saw him this morning
Through a chink of wainscot that divides my lodging
sp.p: And the host of the house, withdraw my host, and hostess, the fair Biancha, and an ancient gentlewoman into their bedchamber; I could not overhear their conference, but I saw such a mass of gold and jewels, and when he had done he lock it up into a casket; great joy there was amongst them and forth they are gone into the city, and my host told me at his going forth he thought he should not return till after supper; now sir, in their absence will we fall to our picklocks, enter the chamber, seize the jewels, make an escape from Florence, and we are made for ever.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: But if they should go to a true conjurer, and fetch us back in a whirl wind?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Do not believe there is any such fetch in astrology, and this may be a means to make us live honest hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Tis but an ill road to't that lies through the high way of thieving.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: For indeed I am weary of this trade of fortune-telling, and mean to give all over, when I come into England, for it is a very ticklish quality.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And ith' end will hang by a twine thread.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Besides the island has too many of the profession, they hinder one another's market.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No, no, the pillory hinders their market.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: You know there the juggling captain.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I there's a sure card.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Only the foreman of their jury is dead, but he died like a roman.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Else 'tis thought he had made work for the hangman.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And the very ball of your false prophets, he's quashed too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: He did measure the stars with a false yard, and may now travail to Rome with a mortar on's head to see if he can recover his money that way.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Come, come, let's fish for this casket, and to sea presently.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: We shall never reach London I fear;
My mind runs so much of hanging landing at wapping.
This well may be a day of joy long wished for
To my Clarissa, she is innocent.
Nor can her youth but with an open bosom
Meet Hymen's pleasing bounties, but to me
That am environed with black guilt and horror
It does appear a funeral though promising much
In the conception were hard to manage
But sad in the event, it was not hate
But fond indulgence in me to preserve
Cesarios' threatened life in open court
That forced me to disclaim him, choosing rather
To rob him of his birthright, and honour
Then suffer him to run the hazard of
Enraged Baptista's fury, while he lives;
I know I have a son, and the Duke's sentence
A while deluded, and this tempest over,
When he assures himself despair hath seized him.
I can relieve and raise him — speak, who is it
That presses on my privacies? Sir your pardon.
You cannot come unwelcome, though it were
To read my secret thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Lady to you
Mine shall be ever open; lady said I,
That name keeps too much distance, sister rather
I should have styled you, and I now may claim it,
Since our divided families are made one
By this blessed marriage; to whose honour comes
The Duke in person, waited on by all
The braveries of his court, to witness it,
And then to be our guests, is the bride ready
To meet and entertain him?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: She attends the coming of your son.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Pray you bring her forth.
The Dukes at hand — music in her loud voice,
Speaks his arrival.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: She's prepared to meet it. — exit.

div.stage: Enter Mariana, Clarissa led by two maids: at the other door, Baptista meets with Mentivole, led by two courtiers, the Duke, Bishop; divers attendants: (A song) whilst they salute.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It were impertinent to wish you joy,
Since all joys dwell about you, Hymen's torch
Was never slighted with a luckier omen,
Nor burned with so much splendour, to defer
With fruitless compliment, the means to make
Your certain pleasures lawful to the world;
Since in the union of your hearts they are
Confirmed already: would but argue us
A boaster of our favours; to the temple
And there the sacred knot once tied, all triumphs
Our dukedom can afford, shall grace your nuptials.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: On there.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I hope it is not in the power
Of any to cross us now.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: But in the breath
Of a wronged father I forbid the bands.

sp.speaker: Cesar.
sp.l: What, do you stand at gaze?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Risen from the dead!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Although the sea had vomited up the figure
In which thy better part lived long imprisoned,
True love despising fear, runs thus to meet it.

sp.speaker: Claris.
sp.l: In duty I kneel to it.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Hence vile wretches,
To you I am a substance incorporeal,
And not to be profaned, with your vile touch?
That could so soon forget me, but such things
Are neither worth my anger, nor reproof.
To you great sir, I turn myself and these
Immediate ministers of your government,
And if in my rude language I transgress;
Ascribe it to the cold remembrance of
My services, and not my rugged temper.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speak freely, be thy language never so bitter,
To see thee safe Alberto, signs thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: My pardon? I can need none, if it be not
Received for an offence. I tamely bear
Wrongs, which a slave-born Muscovite would check at.
Why if for treason I had been delivered
Up to the hangman's axe, and this dead trunk
Unworthy of a Christian sepulchre;
Exposed a prey to feed the ravenous vulture,
The memory of the much I oft did for you,
Had you but any touch of gratitude,
Or thought of my deservings, would have stopped you
From these unjust proceedings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hear the motives that did induce us.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I have heard them all,
Your highness' sentence, the whole court abused,
By the perjuries, and practice of this woman.
(We pest thou crocodile) my hopeful son,
Whom I dare swear mine own, degraded of
The honours that descend to him from me:
And from that in his love scorned by a creature
Whose base birth though made eminent by her beauty,
Might well have marked her out Cesarios servant,
All this I could have pardoned and forgotten;
But that my daughter with my whole estate
So hardly purchased, is assigned a dower;
To one whose father, and whose family
I so detest; that I would lose my essence
And be transformed to a basilisk
To look them dead, to me's an injury,
Admits no satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: There's none offered.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Nor would not be accepted,
Though upon thy knees 'twere tendered.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Now the storm grows high.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: But that I thought thee dead, and in thy death
The briny ocean had entombed thy name;
I would have sought a wife in a bordello
For my Mentivole, and gladly hugged
Her spurious issue as my lawful nephews,
Before his blood should ere have mixed with thine;
So much I scorn it.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I'll not bandy words, but thus dissolve the contract.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: There I meet thee, and seize on what's mine own.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: For all my service,
Great sir grant me the combat with this wretch,
That I may scourge his insolence.

sp.speaker: Baptist.
sp.l: I kneel for it.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.l: And to approve myself Alberto's son,
I'll be his second upon any odds,
'Gainst him that dare most of Baptista's race.

sp.speaker: Menti.
sp.l: Already upon honourable terms,
In me thou hast met thy better, for her sake
I'll add no more.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Sir, let our swords decide it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O stay sir, and as you would hold the title
Of a just prince, ere you grant licence to
These madmen's fury, lend your private ear
To the most distressed of women.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Speak, 'tis granted. He takes Mariana aside.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In the mean time, let not Clarissa be
A patient looker on, though as yet doubtful,
To whom to bend her knee first, yet to all
I stoop thus low in duty, and would wash
The dust of fury with my virgin tears,
From his blessed feet, and make them beautiful
That would move to conditions of peace,
Though with a snail like pace, they all are winged
To bear you to destruction: reverend sirs,
Think on your ancient friendship cemented
With so much blood, but shed in noble action,
Divided now in passion for a brawl;
The makers blush to own, much loved Caesario.
Brother, or friend, (Each title may prevail,)
Remember with what tenderness from our childhood
We loved together, you preferring me
Before yourself, and I so fond of you
That it begotten suspicion in ill minds
That our affection was incestuous.
Think of that happy time, in which I know
That with your dearest blood you had prevented
This shower of tears from me Mentivole,
My husband, registered in that bright star-chamber,
Though now on earth made strangers, be the example
And offer in one hand the peaceful olive
Of concord ▪ or if that can be denied
By powerful intercession in the other
Carry the Hermian rod and force atonement,
Now we will not be all marble. Death's the worst then
And he shall be my bridegroom,Offers to kill herself

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Hold Clarissa, his loving violence needs must
Offer inspite of honour— he snatches away her knife and sets it to his own breast, she stays his hand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Was it to that end then on your religion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And my hope in heaven sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We then will leave entreaties, and make use
Of our authority, must I cry ay me
To this unheard of insolence? in my presence
To draw your swords, and as all reverence
That's due to majesty were forfeited,
Cherish this wilderness! sheathe them instantly,
And show an alteration in your looks, or by my power

sp.speaker: Alber,
sp.l: Cut of my head

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: And mine, rather than hear of peace with this bad man.
I'll not alone give up my throat, but suffer
Your rage to reach my family.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And my name to be no more remembered.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Biancha, 'tis Biancha, still Biancha: but strangely altered.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: If that thirteen years
Of absence could raze from my memory
The figure of my friend, I might forget thee;
But if thy image be graven on my heart,
Thou art my Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou my Baptista?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A sudden change!

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I dare not ask dear friend
If Juliana live! for that's a blessing
I am unworthy of, but yet deny not
To let me know the place she hath made happy
By having there her sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: If your highness please to vouchsafe a patient
Ear we shall make a true relation of a story
That shall call on your wonder.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speak, we hear you.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Baptista's fortune in the Genoa court,
His banishment, with his fair wife's restraint
You are acquainted with; what since hath followed
I faithfully will deliver, ere eight moons
After Baptista's absence were complete,
Fair Juliana found the pleasures that
They had enjoyed together were not barren,
And blushing at the burden of her womb,
No father near to own it, it drew on
A violent sickness, which called down compassion
From the angry Duke, then careful of her health.
Physicians were enquired of, and their judgement
Prescribed the baths of Luca as a means
For her recovery; to my charge it pleased her
To be committed; but as on the way
We journeyed, those throws only known to women
Came thick upon her, in a private village.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: She died?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Have patience, she brought to the world
A hopeful daughter; for her body's sickness
It soon decayed, but the grief of her mind
Hourly increased, and life grew tedious to her,
And desperate ere to see you; she enjoined me
To place her in a Greekish monastery,
And to my care gave up her pretty daughter.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: What monastery? as a pilgrim barefoot,
I'll search it out.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Pray you interrupt me not,
Now to my fortunes; the girl well disposed off
With a faithful friend of mine, my cruel fate
Made me a prisoner to the Turkish galleys,
Where for 12 years, these hands tugged at the oar,
But fortune tired at length with my afflictions,
Some ships of Malta met the Ottoman fleet,
Charged them and boarded them, and gave me freedom
With my deliverers I served, and got
Such reputation with the great master
That he gave me command over a tall
And lusty ship, where my first happy service
Was to redeem Alberto rumoured dead,
But was like me surprised by Cortugogly.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I would I had died there.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: And from him learning
Baptista lived, and their dissolved friendship,
I hoist up sails for Greece, found Juliana
A votary at her beads; having made known
Both that you lived, and where you were, she borrowed
So much from her devotion as to wish me
To bring her to you; if the object please you,
With joy receive her.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Rage and fury leave me -Throws away his sword
I am so full of happiness, there's no room left
To entertain you, oh my long lost jewel,
Light of mine eyes, my soul's strength.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: My best lord, having embraced you thus,
Death cannot fright me.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Live long to do so though i should fix here.
Pardon me Prospero though I inquire my daughter's fortune.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: That your happiness
May be at all parts perfect, here she is!

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Biancha daughter to a Princess.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: True with my faithful host I left her,
And with him till now she hath resided,
Ignorant both of her birth and greatness.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: O my blessed one. Joy upon joy overwhelms me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Above wonder.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I do begin to melt too, this strange story
Works much upon me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Since it hath pleased heaven
To grace us with this miracle, I that am
Heaven's instrument here, determine thus; Alberto
Be not unthankful for the blessings shown you,
Nor you Baptista; discord was yet never
A welcome sacrifice; therefore rage laid by,
Embrace as friends, and let passed difference
Be as a dream forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: 'Tis to me.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: And me, and thus confirm it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And to tie it
In bonds not to be broken, with the marriage ▪
Of young Mentivole, and fair Clarissa,
So you consent great lady, your Biancha
Shall call Caesario husband.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: 'Tis a motion I gladly yield too.

sp.speaker: Caesar.
sp.p: One in which you make a sad man happy. Offers to kneel.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Kneel not, all forgiven.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: With the Duke your uncle I will make atonement, and will have no denial.

div.stage: Enter host, Forobosco, clown and officers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let this day be still held sacred.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Now if you can conjure, let the devil unbind you,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: We are both undone,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Already we feel it.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Justice sir,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I can resolve you, slaves freed from the galleys
By the viceroy of Sicilia.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's their offence?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: The robbing me of all my plate and jewels,
I mean the attempting of it,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Please your grace I will now discover this varlet in earnest, this honest pestilent rogue, professed the art on conjuring, but all the skill that ever he had in the black art was in making a seacole fire; only with wearing strange shapes he begotten admiration amongst fools and women.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Wilt thou preach thou varlet?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why does he goggle with his eyes, and stalk so?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This is one of his magical raptures.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I do vilify your censure, you demand if I am guilty, whir says my cloak by a trick so legerdemain, now I am not guilty, I am guarded with innocence, pure silver lace I assure you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Thus have I read to you your virtues, which notwithstanding I would not have you proud of.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Out thou concealment of tallow, and counterfeit mummia.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To the galleys with them both.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The only sea physic for a knave in to be basted in a galley with the oil of a bull's pizzle.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And will not you make a sour face at the same sauce, sirrah? I hope to find thee so lean, in one fortnight thou mayest be drawn by the ears through the hoop of a firkin.

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.p: Divide them and away with them to'th galleys.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This will take down your pride juggler.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This day that hath given birth to blessings; beyond hope, admits no criminal sentence, to the temple and there with humbleness praise heavens bounties;
sp.l: For blessings ne'er descend from thence, but when
A sacrifice in thanks ascends from men. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: Plays have their fates, not as in their true sense
They're understood, but as the influence
Of idle custom madly works upon
The dross of many tongued opinion.
For language, modest mirth, conceit or wit,
Meets often times with the sweet commendation
Of hang't, 'tis scurvy, when for approbation
A jig shall be clapped at, and every rhyme
Praised and applauded by a clamorous chime.
Let ignorance and laughter dwell together,
They are beneath the muse's pity. Hither
Come nobler judgements, and to those the strain
Of our invention is not bent in vain.
The fair maid of the inn to you commends
Her hopes and welcomes, and withal intends
In th' entertains to which she doth invite ye,
All things to please, and some things to delight ye.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
